content.text: Well, another year and this one has absolutely flown by. It‚Äôs so funny, now that I‚Äôm keeping these sort of life logs/updates, despite this feeling that the year has gone by in a single breath, I can be reminded of just how much has happened, and how many different phases can exist within such a small span of time. Just looking back at the most recent post that I made and thinking how could those events have been just a summer ago - but then again, there was a time when a summer was practically a lifetime. Anyways check it out now I can be even more obnoxious about what music I‚Äôve been listening to lately and I *will* be using it to separate every paragraph. This one‚Äôs a banger

In the last few months, despite my last post‚Äôs prediction, I did not get through a ton of my game backlog, and in fact I accidentally wiped a 15 hour Pokemon Let‚Äôs Go Pikachu save which properly ruined one of my nights. I did get a good deal of reading in though, doing an 8 hour readathon, and finally catching up with the Yotsubato! Series, which has quickly shot up my list of some of my favorite media of all time (Definitely cried reading the randoseru chapter). And also on the gaming front, I did some game dev for the first time since college, doing a game jam with Max and making a crappy sheep puzzle game in one weekend. Definitely motivated me to keep making and I‚Äôve been stewing on how I might be able to up the ante and commit to a larger project.

In July, I went camping in Olympic National park for a few nights with Lydia and it was really such an incredible time. Even though I was still pretty incapacitated due to the shoulder at that time, we managed to have a good time just enjoying the more leisurely hikes, and fun camping vibes. We also had a run in with the tides and questionable decision making that led to quite the adventure. Mix it all in with a hammock and some Doritos nachos and you could probably guess that I had the time of my life. I was also so lucky to have my parents visit me this summer too, and I had the privilege of going to another Dead and Company show with them. We also found our way to the Ruth Asawa SFMOMA exhibit which was really quite stunning.

Yesterday was my 24th birthday, and like most years, I had put off planning anything until the last moment. It‚Äôs just too much for my socially anxious head. Lucky for me though, I came home from work the day before to find Lydia, who had bought tickets as soon as she heard I wasn‚Äôt going to Riot Fest, waiting to surprise me in my apartment. Not only that, but I got hit with the double whammy when she sneakily led me to Dolores Park, with friends and a cake lying in wait. Truly, the takeaway here is that I am perhaps much more gullible than I would have thought. I really did have such a perfect weekend though, and I‚Äôm extremely thankful.

Lastly, just some miscellaneous things in the photos - I did *finally* make it to the Nintendo store on my third try, which made for a good excuse to crochet a flower for the Pikmin vase I bought as a gift, Saw Cheekface in concert for the nth time, finally got a PlayDate which I have been wanting for ages ((Thank you max if you are reading this, it‚Äôs actually the best and I‚Äôm having so much fun with it)), saw some DWS competition climbing in China Basin, got to see some old friends, am back skating and climbing bit after months of PT, and just generally am having a great time. I feel as if whenever my birthday comes around (or new years or something similar), there‚Äôs always questions of what‚Äôs next or what do you want to improve, and while I definitely have my fair share of goals and aims before I turn 25 (help), for this post I‚Äôll just bask in what was my 23. Thanks to anyone who‚Äôs reading, or has been a part of my year in any way, shape or form. Bye bye!

Today, I‚Äôm feeling thankful. Well, I suppose most days I‚Äôm feeling thankful, but today I‚Äôm feeling thankful ~and~ bored on Memorial Day, so here I am. There are many different takes on the ‚Äúlife is a book‚Äù cliche, but I really enjoy the way my dad used to remind me of it (and still does to this day) - that every day you get to write a page, and all that matters is that the day that you finally close the book, that you‚Äôre proud of the story you‚Äôve written. It‚Äôs something that comes up in my mind often, and as I write these posts, always comes to the forefront of my thought. I always find myself smiling, thinking how lucky I am to be able to write a chapter every 3 months and be so happy with its contents. And I have everyone in my life to thank for it.

Something I‚Äôve felt recently is that despite how hard I may try, I‚Äôm actually not the one writing my book, I‚Äôm more like the editor. My mom and dad formed the personality of the titular character (yes, me, pretentiously), my friends and anyone else who I‚Äôve received love or support from have been the driving force behind any successful moments, and all the characters, environments, and challenges, have minds of their own. And yet somehow, despite this absolutely raging ball of chaos that determines one‚Äôs book, I‚Äôve ended up with this one. One that I wouldn‚Äôt trade for any other book in the library of fates. How lucky I was to be born to loving parents, with a loving brother and sister. How lucky I was to have friends by my side every step of the way. To have been able to be lifted up by others so that I may find my own form of success, whatever way one may choose to define it. To still be here, alive and healthy, 23 years later.

Anyway not really sure where all that came from but suffice to say I‚Äôm filled with love and appreciation for anyone who has made me the person I am today - but back to our regular scheduled programming. I‚Äôve been up to a good bit these last couple months. Finished my first book in Japanese, bought some snowboard gear and went out to Tahoe for the weekend, tried (and failed) twice to go to the new Nintendo store in SF, hosted a barbecue/game night at the apartment, made some homemade magnets as well as a little crochet hat for my smiski, helped Lydia at her first art vending event, spent time in Seattle, hitchhiked for the first time, did some hiking and a good chunk of outdoor climbing, and even sent a handful of my first V6s before ultimately dislocating my shoulder on one ·ï¶(√≤_√≥Àá)·ï§

As such I‚Äôll probably be doing a lot more sedentary activity for the next month or so at least, so I‚Äôm hoping to finally make it through a chunk of my book and game backlog that has been haunting me, but we'll have to wait and see I suppose! Thanks for taking time to read this :) til next time :p

title: 2025, a year of japanese, and ‚Ä¶ more?

content.text: Hello hello time for another blog post üòé

Well to start, this post is gonna be about pretty much everything since last time, but notably I‚Äôll have a section for the new year and also my japanese learning anniversary? Maybe? Idk well see. Pics at the bottom as always (I should really add image embedding but I‚Äôm lazy. Maybe next time.

So it‚Äôs a new year! And I, like many other members of the masses, was influenced upon by social media. What I mean when I say that, is people online were making ‚Äòbingo cards‚Äô of goals for the new year instead of resolutions. The concept is that since you‚Äôre making more of a checklist rather than things you can fail at, you‚Äôre more inclined to keep going even if you slip up every now and then. Plus, you only really need to get 5/25 for a bingo (four with the free space!) It caught on pretty fast, and well I guess I can be a sheep sometimes because I loved the idea and made my own! You can check out my crappy gimp bingo board below, but I‚Äôm really excited about it. Plus, one of my goals for the year is 4 blog posts so I‚Äôm really cooking right now (why do you think I‚Äôm writing this at the ¬º year mark haha) Anyway, I think it‚Äôs been great so far! I‚Äôve got my board printed out next to my door, and I have a sticky note for each goal where I can track progress or related items - It‚Äôs been fun and I like having small reminders of what I want to be doing. Anyway, seeing as this is the ¬º year mark I figured i‚Äôd do a little data analysis (simple math) and see how things are coming along. I divided my goals into 2 categories, ones that are countables (do x, y times) and ones that are black and white. For the countables, I‚Äôm an average of 29.5% of the way through!!!! Pretty good right? Well, unfortunately I‚Äôve only completed 2 of the 16 black or white ones‚Ä¶ 12.5%. Less good. Oh well, those are not as black and white as I make them out to be statistically so I think it‚Äôs going alright haha. That‚Äôs enough of that I guess but I‚Äôm pretty proud of what I‚Äôve managed so far and it‚Äôs shaping up to be a good year!

Moving on to my Japanese learning anniversary, today is the very day I started, a year ago (or at least, it‚Äôs when I placed an order on amazon for the Genki Textbooks, so more or less haha). It turns out when you start learning a language, you very often get asked why you are learning. Looking back, I really am not sure why I started other than my upcoming trip, but I‚Äôm super glad I did, it‚Äôs become quite the hobby for me. There are days when I think how have I accomplished so little in a year, and there are days when I cannot believe how far I‚Äôve come. Luckily, today I‚Äôm feeling good. It‚Äôs insane to think that I didn‚Äôt know the first thing a year ago. Some stuff I‚Äôve accomplished in my first year. Read Genki I+2 Textbooks as well as their workbooks and supplemental videos, hit 5000 cards in Anki (although theres likely a handful of duplicates in there haha), made it to Level 25 on WaniKani, managed a few crappy conversations, listened to 500+ Nihongo Con Teppei episodes (lol), read a ton of Satori Reader stories and graded readers, 15 (!) Manga volumes, 1 children‚Äôs book (frog and toad <3), watched the brand new DragonBall Daima series, and a handful of movies. I recently started reading my first ‚Äúfull novel‚Äù (targeted at middle schoolers but a win is a win) Kiki‚Äôs Delivery Service, and I‚Äôm about 80 pages in. I‚Äôm really so so happy with my progress - When I was in japan only 8 months ago, I bought some books thinking they would be completely unreadable for another 3 years, but are now totally within reach. It‚Äôs a great feeling going from confusing katakana left and right to being able to read, listen, and speak (even if it‚Äôs like a baby). That said, there is still a super long road ahead! This post is already stupid long, so I‚Äôm not gonna put too much time into thinking about it, but I‚Äôm gonna set a few goals here for the next year to hopefully achieve before March rolls around again. Guess I‚Äôm gonna have to add list functionality to my site for this huh. Anyway I hope to:

items: Do at least 25 hours of speaking practice
Take the N3 ( just to measure progress :p )

content.text: We‚Äôll see how these things actually shake out, but regardless, I‚Äôm pretty excited for another year of this - it‚Äôs only getting more fun as I get better!

Okay okay I‚Äôm gonna wrap this up. Some other things that have been going on! (and can mostly be seen in the photos). I crocheted some flowers, and a little net thing for my bedside lamp, as well as more sunflower coasters for a housewarming gift. I did some traveling back home, to seattle, and out to LA! I had to rebuild my skateboard table/stool things because my poor craftsmanship sadly faltered while miles was eating lunch. Hit 6 months as a corporate boy. I went outdoor bouldering for the first time. Got to see Christian Lee Hutson, and Dawes again of course. Been generally just enjoying my time in san francisco. Also Ironically, almost a year since I created this as an outlet bc I missed my social media fix, I‚Äôve finally completely stopped using Instagram, which has been nice. Theres other things I‚Äôm missing but yeah! Things have been good. As per uuuusual - if you read all this, I‚Äôm sorry. But thanks for caring! Hope it was mildly entertaining enough. See ya!

title: The first months in San Francisco

content.text: It's been a while, and today I just suppose I feel like writing. And I have many reasons for that feeling; not only has it been a busy and eventful few months, but the seasons are starting to change, I'll be heading home for thanksgiving in just a couple days, and I‚Äôve recently been feeling the weight of all the change. I‚Äôve noticed I feel compelled to write when I‚Äôm feeling a little down, and the permanence of the move has been hitting me lately. And on top of that, I‚Äôm on call for work at the moment - so it‚Äôs not like I‚Äôve got anything better to be doing. As always, photos are all down at the bottom!

Since I last wrote, I drove across the country to San Francisco with my dad who helped me move into my new apartment. As I mentioned in my last post, I was SO excited, and immediately got to work on making it feel like home. This ended up being a disaster, as my landlord let me know he‚Äôd be terminating the lease less than a week later. Mix that together with trying to find a new place last second, starting my first real job, and a few other emotional hurdles and I had quite a head spin for my first 4 or so weeks in SF. Now that the dust has settled though, I really am glad that things turned out this way. I love my current apartment and spent a couple weeks busying myself with some DIY projects to make it feel a bit more homely. I made some side table/benches out of some old skateboards, crocheted some sunflower coasters, made a sick pendant light for our living room, painted a shelf, crocheted a really long ass vine to wrap around the pipe in my bedroom, and just in general had a ton of fun putting up shelves and playing interior designer for a month or so. Not to mention, the view is fantastic and Miles is a great roommate.

SF has been lovely, and now that things are taking a turn for the colder, I‚Äôm really starting to appreciate how wonderful the weather has been these last few months. Getting to enjoy long days in the park with friends, going on hikes just outside the city, or just riding a bike along the water on sunday to go get my groceries, it‚Äôs been wonderful. I‚Äôve also felt the pleasures of being in a big city and having all my favorite bands come through. I got to see Foxing tour their new album (which has become my new favourite thing to yell/cry along to when I‚Äôm having a bad day), and Julien Baker who I have been wanting to see since I was 15!! During the summery months at least, it feels like there‚Äôs always some event going on or a market nearby that begs checking out. I really like it here.

I think one of my biggest fears when moving was isolation from the people I care about. Yes, I‚Äôd be moving close to some of my friends, but I would be moving very far from a lot of the people I care deeply about, and farther from my family than I‚Äôve ever been. While I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve successfully 100% staved off loneliness, I‚Äôve been so relieved to feel still connected to a lot of my friends. Catching up through text or over the phone has become one of my favorite pastimes. If you‚Äôve messaged me or called me even just once in the past 3 months, from the bottom of my heart, thank you. It means the world. If you‚Äôre reading this and you haven‚Äôt (or even if you have), please do! I probably want to hear from you :)

Outside of all the above, I‚Äôve still been chipping away at my Japanese learning and am pretty pleased with my progress, even if it‚Äôs a bit slower than I would like (I started reading Yotsuba To! And it single-handedly puts the largest smile on my face with every passing chapter). I‚Äôve been keeping up with my bouldering, which I have to say having an awesome gym a 5 minute walk away is game changing. And just generally trying to enjoy myself to the best of my abilities. Eating good food, reading a lot, and listening to music/playing guitar whenever I get the chance. Like all stages in my life, lots has changed, and also nothing has. There are happy days and sad. I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôd say I‚Äôve really settled in here yet, but I‚Äôm working on it.
If you read this to the end, or at all, you‚Äôre the best. Peace <3

title: Travels in Hawaii and Japan, and a look into what's next

content.text: Long time, no see! It's Jonah (Surprise!) I've just returned to Texas a few days ago after a little over 5 weeks away, and wow what a time I've had. Scuba diving, climbing mountains, and exploring new cities with old friends and new - it's truly been the time of my life. More about both adventures below!

To begin, a week in Hawaii with my family. At this point in time I was in desperate need of getting out of the house. Two weeks of scuba training in the rear view and I was ready to get on the road. I admittedly went into this part of my trip with far too low expectations. I was thinking of it as a pit stop on my way to Japan. I had always sort of viewed Hawai'i as a spot for beach vacations and not much else, but the island of Kauai proved me so wrong. To start, I got to go scuba diving with my brother and my dad, an experience I'll cherish for the rest of my life. Swimming down low with the eels, turtles, fish, and my family was surreal. I just had a blast the whole time I was on the island. While we didn't get to do the Kalalau trail, we did some other amazing hikes and some beautiful seaside biking. The boat ride up the Na Pali coast was also unforgettable. For only a week, this trip was such a joy filled time that I'm so grateful I got to share with my family before heading off to Tokyo on my own.

As this was my first time overseas as an adult, and my first vacation on my own, this trip was bound to be special to me - but Japan was, to be cliche, the trip of a lifetime for me. There are few things in my life thus far that have felt so significant to me. This trip was a pilgrimage not just for me, but for 6 year old me, sitting under the covers after dark, attempting to force feed my level 70 Charizard down the throats of the Elite Four in Pokemon Fire Red. For all the versions of me that I've been since that day. The ones who found love for language, origami, manga, games, food, music, adventure, culture, and more. I've quenched an age old thirst of mine, but also birthed new ones. I've only grown more excited to go on more journeys and learn and grow as much as I can. Dramatic words aside, I've truly done things in this past month that I've dreamt of for my entire life, and other things beyond those dreams. I'd be a fool to try to recount half of what I've enjoyed in this single blog post, but hopefully my words and the photos below can give you an idea.

Throughout my time in Japan I had so many moments that made me go, "Am I really here? Is this really happening?" Am I really in Japan right now? Am I really at a sumo tournament? Did I really just share a lovely cup of tea and a (very) broken conversation with a kind stranger in Japanese? Am I really at the top of Mount Fuji watching the sun rise over the Kanto region? The list goes on. I visited so many cities, and met wonderful people, some in passing, and others who I hope to stay close to for a long time to come. Without writing a book, I'm going to list just a handful of some of my great joys totally out of context from my trip. Enjoy! The beautiful garden of Guesthouse Toco, Meeting up with Taka and staying out all night at Karaoke in Shibuya, Pokemon Cafe, The gorgeous Meiji Shrine, Fukuzumiro Ryokan in Hakone, The beautiful view from the top of Fuji San and my lovely spontaneous hiking buddies, a day off in Kyoto with Ruby, the lovely old woman who offered me tea and a book of her father's poems in her craftshop, beautiful ukiyo-e museums, secondhand shopping at book-off and retro game stores, The Pax Hostel and all it's inhabitants, jazz clubs, a relaxed day in Osaka with Spencer, Ghibli Park and it's magic, the Sumo tournament, omakase from the local izakaya, the beauty of Kamikochi, the grueling yet rewarding peak of Yarigatake, the lovely nature days with Paige, the onsen at the bottom of the mountain, the harrowing yet hopeful hiroshima, learning to make gyoza, the ghibli museum, Tokyo, Hakone, Osaka, Nara, Hiroshima, Kyoto, Kamikochi, Miyajima, Kawaguchiko, Nagoya, the pokemon centers, the nintendo stores, the unmatched beauty of all of the shrines and parks I visited, the goshuin I recorded in my goshuin-cho, the lovely and helpful strangers i met, the new friends I've made, the memories I will keep and forever cherish.
ÁöÜ„Åï„Çì„ÅÇ„Çä„Åå„Å®„ÅÜ„Åî„Åñ„ÅÑ„Åæ„ÅôÔºÅ

I now sit at home, fulfilled, and ready to look ahead. I start my new job at Amazon in San Francisco in just two weeks. I'm quite excited, and just a little nervous. I plan to spend the next two weeks enjoying all the time that I can with my family, and hopefully seeing a few friends while I remain in town. I've already packed just about everything up, and while it feels weird to finally have my childhood room completely cleared out, it feels like the right time. I'm excited to take tokens from this part of my life into the next. I've already been doing a lot of brewing in my head as to how I'll design and curate my space, and I can't wait to really get my hands on it and make it my home. I'm also eager to start working, and paving a life of my own out in the bay. Even though I'm sure things will be different than how it was for me as an intern last year, I'm confident I will find my place there. My goals for my first few months are to push myself to work hard all the time at my job, while not losing sight of the things that are important to me. I want to keep pursuing Japanese with fervor, stay close to my friends, and pursue more creative projects (I've recently been challenged to try my hand at a leather wallet so I guess that's next). I'll be sure to leave an update soon. Peace <3

title: The first post, updates, and what this is all for

content.text: Hello! This is my first post on this blog of mine. I'm hoping to use this as kind of a space to leave updates on my life, projects, career stuff - really whatever. I think I've been feeling pretty disillusioned with social media over the last year, but I still love having a place to organize my thoughts and put them out there for anyone that might want to see what I'm up to. Now yes, I could use Instagram or Twitter or something, but this feels a lot less performative and more safe. If you're reading this - you had to actually want to come to this page, it didn't just get plopped into your endless feed. So, from here on out, I'll be posting here whenever I like. Each post will hopefully have a little bit of updates and some photos, but I'm not going to be strict on myself. Whatever comes, will come.

Anyway, What ~has~ been going on? Well to start, I've just graduated! I earned my BSE in Computer Science from the University of Michigan just a few weeks ago. I had such an amazing senior year (photos of which you can find below), and I accomplished so much. You can read about my creative endeavors through this medium article I wrote for Shift.
Read the article here

So yeah, I'm really stoked on those projects - especially having made a real gameboy game. Way cool. Now, looking forward, I'm starting as a full time SDE at Amazon in August. I'll be moving out to San Francisco and couldn't be more excited. I'm so grateful to be in a city that is high proximity to so much natural beauty. Before all that though, I've got some time at home with family followed by a week in Hawaii where I'll be scuba diving, which will subsequently be followed by a month solo in Japan. I have always wanted to go to Japan, so be sure to keep an eye out for an absurdly long post about that. Anyway I think that's kind of it for now, but I'll write more soon. Photos below! Peace <3
